Title: Prove that $\int_0^{\infty} \frac{\sin(2013 x)}{x(\cos x+\cosh x)}dx=\frac{\pi}{4}$
AcceptedAnswer:
Because the integrand is even, contour integration yields
$$
\begin{align}
&\int_0^\infty\frac{\sin(mx)}{x(\cos(x)+\cosh(x))}\mathrm{d}x\\
&=\frac12\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{\sin(mx)}{x(\cos(x)+\cosh(x))}\mathrm{d}x\\
&=\frac12\int_{-\infty-i}^{\infty-i}\frac{\sin(mx)}{x(\cos(x)+\cosh(x))}\mathrm{d}x\\
&=\frac1{4i}\int_{\gamma^+}\frac{e^{imz}}{z(\cos(z)+\cosh(z))}\mathrm{d}z
-\frac1{4i}\int_{\gamma^-}\frac{e^{-imz}}{z(\cos(z)+\cosh(z))}\mathrm{d}z\\
&=\frac{2\pi i}{4i}\frac12
+2\frac{2\pi i}{4i}\sum_{k=0}^\infty(-1)^{k+1}\frac{\mathrm{sech}\left(\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}{\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi}\frac{\cos\left(m\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}{\exp\left(m\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}\\
&=\frac\pi4+\pi\sum_{k=0}^\infty(-1)^{k+1}\frac{\mathrm{sech}\left(\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}{\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi}\frac{\cos\left(m\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}{\exp\left(m\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}\\
&=\frac\pi4\qquad\text{for odd $m$}
\end{align}
$$
where $\gamma^+$ goes from $-R-i$ to $+R-i$ then circles counterclockwise back in the upper half plane along $|z+i|=R$ and $\gamma^+$ goes from $-R-i$ to $+R-i$ then circles clockwise back in the lower half plane along $|z+i|=R$. The residue of $f(z)=\dfrac{e^{imz}}{z(\cos(z)+\cosh(z))}$ at $z=0$ is $\frac12$. Let $\alpha=\frac{1+i}{2}$. As noted in this answer , $f$ has singularities at $\pm(2k+1)\pi\alpha$ and $\pm(2k+1)\pi\overline{\alpha}$. The sum of the residues in the upper half plane at $(2k+1)\pi\alpha$ and $-(2k+1)\pi\overline{\alpha}$ is the same as the sum of the residues in the lower half plane at $(2k+1)\pi\overline{\alpha}$ and $-(2k+1)\pi\alpha$. Both are equal to
$$
(-1)^{k+1}\frac{\mathrm{sech}\left(\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}{\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi}\frac{\cos\left(m\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}{\exp\left(m\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\right)}
$$
Note that for odd $m$, these are all $0$; $x=m\frac{2k+1}{2}\pi\equiv\frac\pi2\pmod{\pi}\Rightarrow\cos(x)=0$. This is not so for even $m$. Thus,
$$
\int_0^\infty\frac{\sin(2013x)}{x(\cos(x)+\cosh(x))}\mathrm{d}x=\frac\pi4
$$

The proposition to be proven is:
$$ \int_0^\infty\frac{\sin(2013x)}{x(\cos(x)+\cosh(x))}\mathrm{d}x=\frac\pi4 $$

Our review finds that this proposition is **false**. Consequently, any proof attempting to establish this equality must contain a flaw. The correct value of the integral is not $\frac{\pi}{4}$. We will derive the correct value for the integral, which depends on the parameter $a=2013$.

We can evaluate this integral using Plancherel's theorem for Fourier transforms. The theorem states that for two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ with Fourier transforms $F(k)$ and $G(k)$, the following identity holds:
$$ \int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x) g^*(x) dx = \int_{-\infty}^\infty F(k) G^*(k) dk $$

    $$ F(k) = \mathcal{F}\left\{\frac{\sin(ax)}{x}\right\}(k) = \begin{cases} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}} & \text{if } |k| < a \\ 0 & \text{if } |k| > a \end{cases} $$

3.  **Compute the Fourier transform of g(x):**
    The Fourier transform of $g(x) = \frac{1}{\cos(x)+\cosh(x)}$ is given by:
    $$ G(k) = \mathcal{F}\left\{\frac{1}{\cos x + \cosh x}\right\}(k) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{e^{-ikx}}{\cos x + \cosh x} dx $$
    Since $g(x)$ is even, this simplifies to a cosine transform:
    $$ G(k) = \sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}} \int_0^\infty \frac{\cos(kx)}{\cos x + \cosh x} dx $$
    A known integral identity is $\int_0^\infty \frac{\cos(kx)}{\cos x + \cosh x} dx = \frac{\pi}{2\cosh(k\pi/2)}$.

    $$ 2I(a) = 2 \cdot \frac{\pi}{2} \int_0^a \text{sech}\left(\frac{k\pi}{2}\right) dk = \pi \int_0^a \text{sech}\left(\frac{k\pi}{2}\right) dk $$

    The antiderivative of $\text{sech}(u)$ is $\arctan(\sinh(u))$.
